Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story:
I was halfway through scrubbing the kitchen floor, my wife calling out from the living room about the guest towels and whether I’d remembered to pick up the special tea her aunt likes. The house was a whirlwind of last-minute cleaning, and I could feel her stress radiating through every request. I wanted to be present, to help, to share the load as I’d promised. But my phone buzzed insistently—my clerk’s urgent message. I was needed in court, right now. 

Minutes later, I stood in my robes, instructing the jury, my mind still half at home. Suddenly, my clerk slipped me a note: the Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent I was using. Everything I’d prepared was now wrong. I had to stop, reassess, and rewrite my instructions on the spot. The weight of the courtroom’s expectation pressed down on me, but so did the image of my wife, overwhelmed and alone, preparing for our relatives. I felt torn in two, each role demanding my full attention, neither willing to wait. My heart pounded as I stood there, caught between duty and devotion, knowing I couldn’t be both things at once.
